asset:playlist.asset:name: always_prepare_for_meetings
asset:playlist.asset:title: Always Prepare for Meetings
asset:playlist.asset:description: Christine calls a meeting to discuss international distribution for the company’s new film. But the attendees seem confused and disorganized. A professional coach explains how preparing more rigorously for meetings can help Christine avoid these problems—starting with clarifying four critical aspects of each meeting.
asset:playlist.asset:biography:
Coach

Audrey J. Lee is the Boston-based Principal of consulting firm Perspectiva. She is an experienced trainer specializing in communication, diversity issues, and conflict management. A certified mediator, Audrey helps clients manage critical relationships successfully. Past clients include Novo Nordisk, Desutche Bank, and the Illinois Supreme Court, where she designed and facilitated courses on diversity, communication skills, and professionalism. Perspectiva has had a long-term collaboration with the Harvard Negotiation Project, an ongoing effort to improve negotiation skills through real-world conflict intervention.

Before joining Perspectiva, Audrey worked as an intellectual property and litigation attorney at Winston & Strawn in Chicago and Davis Polk & Warwell in New York.

She lives in Boston and is an instructor both in the Harvard Negotiation Institute and lecturer at University of Massachusetts Boston.

She is a graduate of Harvard College and Harvard Law School.

Actors

Christine Cuddy, who prefers to be called by her last name, is a seasoned actress. She grew up in the Boston area, where she trained in the performing arts. She also learned her trade at the Second City and Annoyance theaters in Chicago. She performs with the Mainstage cast and teaches improv at ImprovBoston. She writes and performs in OBV!, a two-woman show with Megan Goltermann, and has appeared in regional commercials. Christine can be heard on the ImprovBoston podcast with Will Luera and Harry Gordon. Her favorite festival experience is performing in the Improv Allstar Show with Rachel Dratch at the Women in Comedy Festival in Boston.

Other ImprovBoston credits include “Cabin Pressure,” “The A-Team,” “The Real Housewives of the Magick Kingdom,” and “The Lodge,” a three-person show that plays to her biggest strength--being a townie. Christine has performed at improv festivals all over the United States, Ireland, and Spain.Christine graduated from Framingham State University with a degree in communication arts with a focus in acting and directing.

Robert Woo is the Marketing Manager at InsightSquared. A student of viral marketing and comedy, his goal is to mesh these two aspects at every turn in his professional career. Robert tries comedy in improv currently with Hard Left Productions, and stand-up currently in front of a mirror. He writes sketches and web series; acts for various commercials; directs improv off and on; and plays the guitar just enough to maintain his calluses.

Robert has performed in various festivals in Boston, Lowell, Chicago, New York, Providence, Sarasota, Tokyo, Atlanta, Lowell, Vancouver, and Austin.

Robert studied at Tufts University.

Harry Gordon was born in Vermont and began his performing career when he sang “Hard-Hearted Hannah” to his grandparents at the age of seven. He is a performer, writer, instructor, and comedian who earned his chops at the Improv Asylum in Boston’s North End and ImprovBoston in Cambridge. He hosts the critically acclaimed “Harry Roasts America!” at ImprovBoston and improvises in a variety of shows and troupes, including Directions. He is an active member of the Greater Boston Zen Center and volunteers for a variety of organizations through them.

Harry has work experience in a variety of fields, including insurance, investment, higher education, consulting, and transportation. He is a Sales Executive at Zipcar in their Zipcar for Business program.

Natalie Baseman is a comedian and a lady. She began writing and performing comedy professionally at ImprovBoston with the comedy groups Maxitor and The Dowry. She is pursuing an MFA in Writing for Screen and Television at the University of Southern California’s School of Cinematic Arts in Los Angeles. She is involved with Abso Lutely Productions and Comedy Bang! Bang! at the University of Southern California.

Natalie has studied with teachers from the Annoyance, I.O., Upright Citizen’s Brigade, and Second City, including Mick Napier. While living in Edinburgh, she worked with the Edinburgh Improverts and the Parisian movement theater company, Dancing Brick. She also wrote/directed the solo sketch comedy show “Part Toaster/Part Worm,” which she has performed in Boston and Los Angeles.
